src: "Mēs zinām daudzus grieķu politiķus, zinātniekus un māksliniekus. Iespējams, ka vispazīstamākais šīs kultūras cilvēks ir Homērs, leģendārais neredzīgais dzejnieks, kurš sacerējis divus grieķu literatūras šedevrus: poēmas ""Iliāda"" un ""Odiseja"". Sofokls un Aristofans joprojām ir populāri dramaturgi, un viņu lugas tiek uzskatītas par daļu no ievērojamākajiem pasaules literatūras darbiem. Vēl viens slavens grieķu matemātiķis ir Pitagors, ko pārsvarā zina dēļ viņa slavenās teorēmas par taisnleņķa trijstūra malu attiecību."
mt: We know many Greek politicians, scientists and artists. Perhaps the most famous person of this culture is Homer, the blind legendary poet who wrote two Greek literary masterpieces: the epics "Iliad" and "Odyssey". Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights, and their plays are considered part of the most important works of world literature. Another famous Greek mathematician is Pythagoras, who is mainly known for his famous theorem about the relationship of the sides of a right triangle.
ref: We know many Greek politicians, scientists, and artists. Possibly the most known person of this culture is Homer, the legendary blind poet, who composed two masterpieces of Greek literature: the poems Iliad and Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights and their plays are considered to be among the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is a mathematician Pythagoras, mostly known for his famous theorem about relations of the sides of right triangles.

src: "Mēs zinām daudzus grieķu politiķus, zinātniekus un māksliniekus. Iespējams, ka vispazīstamākais šīs kultūras cilvēks ir Homērs, leģendārais neredzīgais dzejnieks, kurš sacerējis divus grieķu literatūras šedevrus: poēmas ""Iliāda"" un ""Odiseja"". Sofokls un Aristofans joprojām ir populāri dramaturgi, un viņu lugas tiek uzskatītas par daļu no ievērojamākajiem pasaules literatūras darbiem. Vēl viens slavens grieķu matemātiķis ir Pitagors, ko pārsvarā zina dēļ viņa slavenās teorēmas par taisnleņķa trijstūra malu attiecību."
mt: We know many Greek politicians, scientists and artists. Perhaps the most famous person of this culture is Homer, the blind legendary poet who wrote two Greek literary masterpieces: the epics "Iliad" and "Odyssey". Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights, and their plays are considered part of the most important works of world literature. Another famous Greek mathematician is Pythagoras, who is mainly known for his famous theorem about the relationship of the sides of a right triangle.
ref: We know many Greek politicians, scientists, and artists. Possibly the most known person of this culture is Homer, the legendary blind poet, who composed two masterpieces of Greek literature: the poems Iliad and Odyssey. Sophocles and Aristophanes are still popular playwrights and their plays are considered to be among the greatest works of world literature. Another famous Greek is a mathematician Pythagoras, mostly known for his famous theorem about relations of the sides of right triangles.

src: Tuvu Austrumu siltajā klimatā māja nebija tik svarīga. Ebreju ģimene lielākoties dzīvoja ārā. Sievietes ēdienu gatavoja pagalmā; veikali bija vienkāršas vaļējas letes, kas pavērstas pret ielu. Mājas būvēja no akmens. Kanaānas zemē nebija lielu mežu, tāpēc koksne bija ārkārtīgi dārga.
mt: In the hot climate of the Near East, the house was not so important. The Jewish family mostly lived outdoors. Women prepared food outside; shops were simple wooden stalls facing the street. Houses were built of stone. There were no large forests in Canaan, so wood was very expensive.
ref: In the warm climate of the Middle East, the house was not so important. Most of the life of the Hebrew family happened in the open air. Women did the cooking in the yard; stores were just open counters looking into the street. Stone was used for building houses. There were no large forests in the land of Canaan, so wood was extremely expensive.

src: "Grenlande bija mazapdzīvota. Seno skandināvu sāgas vēsta, ka Ēriks Rudais par slepkavību tika no Islandes izsūtīts trimdā un, dodoties tālāk uz rietumiem, atklāja zemi, kuru nosauca par Grenlandi. Taču, neskatoties uz viņa atklājumu, tajā brīdī tur jau dzīvoja eskimosu ciltis. Lai gan katra bija ""skandināvu"" valsts, starp Dānijas, Zviedrijas, Norvēģijas un Islandes tautām, karaļiem, paražām un vēsturi bija daudzas atšķirības."
mt: "Greenland was sparsely populated. The old Scandinavian sagas tell that Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder and, traveling further west, discovered a land which he named Greenland. However, at the time of his discovery, it was already inhabited by Eskimo tribes. Although each was a "Scandinavian" state, there were many differences between the kings, customs, and histories of the Danish, Swedish, Norwegian, and Icelandic peoples."
ref: Greenland was settled sparsely. In the Norse sagas they say that Erik the Red was exiled from Iceland for murder, and when travelling further west, found Greenland and named it Greenland. But regardless of his discovery, Eskimo tribes were already living there at the time. Though each country was 'Scandinavian', there were many differences between the people, kings, customs and history of Denmark, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.

src: Lai gan lielākā daļa romiešu ēdienu mums būtu pazīstama, tomēr viņiem bija arī daži dīvaini un neparasti svētku ēdieni, tostarp mežacūkas, pāvi, gliemeži un grauzēji, saukti par susuriem. Vēl viena atšķirība bija tā, ka nabadzīgie un sievietes ēda, sēžot krēslos, savukārt bagātajiem vīriešiem patika rīkot kopīgus banketus, kuros viņi ēšanas laikā gulēja uz sāniem. Seno romiešu ēdienos noteikti netika izmantoti produkti, ko Eiropā ieveda no Amerikas vai Āzijas tikai vēlākos gadsimtos. Piemēram, tiem nebija kukurūzas, tomātu, kartupeļu vai kakao, turklāt neviens senais romietis nav nekad pagaršojis tītara gaļu.
mt: Although most Roman dishes are familiar to us, they also had some strange and exotic festival foods, including boars, pigs, foxes and dogs, called susuris. Another difference was that the poor and women ate sitting on stools, while the rich men liked to have big banquets, where they lay on their sides while eating. Certainly, Roman food did not include products that were introduced to Europe from America or Asia only in later centuries. For example, they did not have corn, tomatoes, potatoes or cocoa, and no ancient Roman ever ate beefsteak.
ref: While most of their food would be familiar to us, Romans did have their share of strange or unusual feast items, including wild boar, peacock, snails, and a type of rodent called a dormouse Another difference was that while the poor people and the woman ate their food while sitting in chairs, the rich men liked to have banquets together where they would lounge on their sides while they ate their meals. Ancient Roman meals couldn't have included foods that came to Europe from America or from Asia in later centuries. For instance, they didn't have corn, nor tomatoes, nor potatoes, nor cocoa, and no ancient Roman ever tasted a turkey.

src: "Civilizācija ir īpaša kultūra, ko veido ārkārtīgi liela cilvēku grupa, kuri dzīvo un strādā, savstarpēji sadarbojoties, proti, sabiedrība. Vārds ""civilizācija"" cēlies no latīņu ""civilis"", kas nozīmē civils, saistīts ar latīņu ""civis"", kas nozīmē pilsonis, un ""civitas"", kas nozīmē pilsēta vai pilsētvalsts, un tas arī kaut kā definē sabiedrības lielumu. Pilsētvalstis ir nāciju priekšteči. Civilizācijas kultūra nozīmē zināšanu nodošanu vairākām paaudzēm, paliekošu kultūras ietekmi un tās vienmērīgu izplatīšanos. Mazākas kultūras bieži vien izzūd, neatstājot aiz sevis būtiskas vēstures liecības, un tās netiek atzītas par pilnvērtīgām civilizācijām."
mt: "Civilization is a particular culture that is developed by an extraordinarily large group of people who live and work together, that is, a society. The word "civilization" comes from Latin "civilis", which means civil, related to Latin "civis", which means citizen, and "civitas", which means city or city-state, and it also somehow defines the size of society. City-states are the precursors of nations. The culture of civilization means the transmission of knowledge to several generations, the lasting influence of culture and its continuous spread. Smaller cultures often die out, leaving behind important historical evidence, and are not recognized as full civilizations."
ref: A civilization is a singular culture shared by a significant large group of people who live and work co-operatively, a society. The word civilization comes from the Latin civilis, meaning civil, related to the Latin civis, meaning citizen, and civitas, meaning city or city-state, and that also somehow defines the size of the society. City-states are the precursors of nations. A civilizational culture implies the passing on of knowledge across several generations, a lingering cultural footprint and fair dissemination. Minor cultures often vanish without leaving relevant historic evidence and fail to be recognized as proper civilizations.

src: Drukgyal Dzong ir sagrauts cietoksnis un budistu klosteris Paro rajona augšējā daļā (Phondeja ciematā). Tiek apgalvots, ka 1649. gadā Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel uzcēla cietoksni, lai svinētu uzvaru pār tibetiešu un mongoļu spēkiem. 1951. gadā pēc ugunsgrēka saglabājās tikai dažas Drukgyal Dzong relikvijas, piemēram, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal attēls. Pēc ugunsgrēka cietoksnis tika saglabāts un aizsargāts, tādējādi kļūstot par Butānas vienu no pievilcīgākajām apskates vietām.
mt: 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel built the Drukgyal Dzong fortress to celebrate his victory over Tibetan and Mongolian forces. In 1951, after a fire, only a few relics of Drukgyal Dzong remained, such as a picture of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, thus becoming one of Bhutan's most popular tourist attractions.
ref: The Drukgyal Dzong is a ruined fortress and Buddhist monastery in the upper part of the Paro District (in Phondey Village). It is said that in 1649, Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel created the fortress to commemorate his victory against the Tibetan-Mongol forces. In 1951, a fire caused for only some of the relics of the Drukgyal Dzong to remain, such as the image of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. After the fire, the fortress was preserved and protected, remaining to be one of Bhutan's most sensational attractions.

src: 18. gadsimtā Kambodža bija iespiesta starp divām spēcīgām kaimiņvalstīm — Taizemi un Vjetnamu. 18. gadsimtā taizemieši vairākas reizes iebruka Kambodžā un 1772. gadā viņi iznīcināja Pnompeņu. 18. gs. pēdējos gados vjetnamieši okupēja arī Kambodžu.
mt: 18th century Cambodia was sandwiched between two powerful neighbors — Thailand and Vietnam. In the 18th century, the Thais invaded Cambodia several times and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Penh. In the last decades of the 18th century, the Vietnamese also occupied Cambodia.
ref: During the 18th century Cambodia found itself squeezed between two powerful neighbors, Thailand and Vietnam. The Thais invaded Cambodia several times in the 18th century and in 1772 they destroyed Phnom Phen. In the last years of the 18th century the Vietnamese also invaded Cambodia.

src: 18. gadsimtā Kambodža bija iespiesta starp divām spēcīgām kaimiņvalstīm — Taizemi un Vjetnamu. 18. gadsimtā taizemieši vairākas reizes iebruka Kambodžā un 1772. gadā viņi iznīcināja Pnompeņu. 18. gs. pēdējos gados vjetnamieši okupēja arī Kambodžu.

src: "Taivānas sākums bija 15. gadsimtā, kur garām braucošie Eiropas jūrnieki salas nosaukumu pieraksta kā ""Ilha Formosa"" jeb skaista sala. 1624. gadā Holandes Austrumindijas kompānija izveidoja bāzi Taivānas dienvidrietumos, uzsākot vietējo iedzīvotāju graudaugu audzēšanas prakses pārveidi un nodarbinot ķīniešu strādniekus savās rīsu un cukura plantācijās. 1683. gadā Cjinu dinastijas (1644.-1912. gads) spēki pārņēma kontroli pār Taivānas rietumu un ziemeļu piekrastes zonām un paziņoja par Taivānas kā provinces iekļaušanu Cjinu impērijā 1885. gadā. 1895. gadā pēc sakāves pirmajā Ķīnas-Japānas karā (1894.-1895. gads) Cjinu dinastija parakstīja Šimonoseki līgumu, ar kuru tā nodeva suverēno varu pār Taivānu Japānai, kura valdīja salā līdz 1945. gadam."
mt: "Taiwan began in the 15th century, when European sailors passing by named the island "Ilha Formosa" or "beautiful island". In 1624, the Dutch East India Company established a base in the southwestern part of Taiwan, starting the local indigenous people's rice cultivation practices and employing Chinese laborers in its sugar and rice plantations. In 1683, Qing dynasty (1644-1912) forces took control of the western and northern coastal areas of Taiwan and announced the island's inclusion in the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after defeat in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing dynasty signed the Treaty of Shimonoseki, which ceded sovereign control of Taiwan to Japan, which ruled the island until 1945."
ref: Taiwan beginning start way back in 15th century where European sailors passing by record the island’s name as Ilha Formosa, or beautiful island. In 1624,Dutch East India Company establishes a base in southwestern Taiwan, initiating a transformation in aboriginal grain production practices and employing Chinese laborers to work on its rice and sugar plantations. In 1683, Qing dynasty (1644-1912) forces take control of Taiwan’s western and northern coastal areas and declared Taiwan as a province of the Qing Empire in 1885. In 1895, after defeat in the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895), the Qing government signs the Treaty of Shimonoseki, by which it cedes sovereignty over Taiwan to Japan, which rules the island until 1945.

src: "Taivānas sākums bija 15. gadsimtā, kur garām braucošie Eiropas jūrnieki salas nosaukumu pieraksta kā ""Ilha Formosa"" jeb skaista sala. 1624. gadā Holandes Austrumindijas kompānija izveidoja bāzi Taivānas dienvidrietumos, uzsākot vietējo iedzīvotāju graudaugu audzēšanas prakses pārveidi un nodarbinot ķīniešu strādniekus savās rīsu un cukura plantācijās. 1683. gadā Cjinu dinastijas (1644.-1912. gads) spēki pārņēma kontroli pār Taivānas rietumu un ziemeļu piekrastes zonām un paziņoja par Taivānas kā provinces iekļaušanu Cjinu impērijā 1885. gadā. 1895. gadā pēc sakāves pirmajā Ķīnas-Japānas karā (1894.-1895. gads) Cjinu dinastija parakstīja Šimonoseki līgumu, ar kuru tā nodeva suverēno varu pār Taivānu Japānai, kura valdīja salā līdz 1945. gadam."

src: To sauc par ķīmiskās vielas pH. Jūs varat izveidot indikatoru, izmantojot sarkano kāpostu sulu. Kāpostu sula maina krāsu atkarībā no tā, cik ķīmiskā viela ir skāba vai bāziska (sārmaina). PH līmeni norāda ūdeņraža (H burts savienojumā pH) jonu daudzums pārbaudītajā ķīmiskajā vielā. Ūdeņraža joni ir protoni, kam atdalīti elektroni (jo ūdeņraža atomi sastāv no viena protona un viena elektrona).
mt: This is called the chemical's pH. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. Red cabbage juice changes color depending on how acidic or basic (sour) the chemical is. The pH level indicates the amount of hydrogen (H in the chemical formula) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons with an electron removed (since hydrogen atoms are made of one proton and one electron).
ref: This is called a chemical's pH. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. The cabbage juice changes color depending on how acidic or basic (alkaline) the chemical is. The pH level is indicated by the amount of Hydrogen (the H in pH) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons that had their electrons stripped off them (since Hydrogen atoms consist of one proton and one electron).

ref: This is called a chemical's pH. You can make an indicator using red cabbage juice. The cabbage juice changes color depending on how acidic or basic (alkaline) the chemical is. The pH level is indicated by the amount of Hydrogen (the H in pH) ions in the tested chemical. Hydrogen ions are protons that had their electrons stripped off them (since Hydrogen atoms consist of one proton and one electron).

src: Lauvas ir vissabiedriskākie kaķi, kas dzīvo lielās grupās, ko sauc par bariem. Baru veido viens līdz trīs radniecīgi pieauguši tēviņi un līdz pat trīsdesmit mātītēm un mazuļiem. Mātītes parasti ir cieši saistītas viena ar otru, esot liela māsu un meitu ģimene. Lauvu bari uzvedas līdzīgi kā vilku vai suņu bari — šo abu dzīvnieku uzvedība ir pārsteidzoši līdzīga lauvu (bet ne citu lielo kaķu) uzvedībai — un ir tikpat nāvējoši saviem upuriem.
mt: Lions are the most social of cats, living in prides. A pride consists of one to three related adult males and up to 30 females and their young. Females are usually closely bonded to one another, forming a large mother and daughter clan. Lions' social behavior is strikingly similar to that of wolves and dogs, and is just as deadly to their prey.
ref: Lions are the most social cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides are made up of one to three related adult males, along with as many as thirty females and cubs. The females are usually closely related to each other, being a large family of sisters and daughters. Lion prides act much like packs of wolves or dogs, animals surprisingly similar to lions (but not other big cats) in behavior, and also very deadly to their prey.

src: Lauvas ir vissabiedriskākie kaķi, kas dzīvo lielās grupās, ko sauc par bariem. Baru veido viens līdz trīs radniecīgi pieauguši tēviņi un līdz pat trīsdesmit mātītēm un mazuļiem. Mātītes parasti ir cieši saistītas viena ar otru, esot liela māsu un meitu ģimene. Lauvu bari uzvedas līdzīgi kā vilku vai suņu bari — šo abu dzīvnieku uzvedība ir pārsteidzoši līdzīga lauvu (bet ne citu lielo kaķu) uzvedībai — un ir tikpat nāvējoši saviem upuriem.
mt: Lions are the most social of cats, living in prides. A pride consists of one to three related adult males and up to 30 females and their young. Females are usually closely bonded to one another, forming a large mother and daughter clan. Lions' social behavior is strikingly similar to that of wolves and dogs, and is just as deadly to their prey.
ref: Lions are the most social cats, living in large groups called prides. Prides are made up of one to three related adult males, along with as many as thirty females and cubs. The females are usually closely related to each other, being a large family of sisters and daughters. Lion prides act much like packs of wolves or dogs, animals surprisingly similar to lions (but not other big cats) in behavior, and also very deadly to their prey.

src: Pēc tam ir vairāki vidēja izmēra kaķi, kas ēd vidēja lieluma laupījumu, sākot no trušiem līdz antilopēm un briežiem. Visbeidzot, ir daudz mazu kaķu (tostarp klaiņojošu mājas kaķu), kuri ēd daudz vairāk visdažādākos mazos laupījumus, piemēram, kukaiņus, grauzējus, ķirzakas un putnus. Viņu panākumu noslēpums ir nišas koncepts - īpašs uzdevums, kuru katrs kaķis veic un kas neļauj tam konkurēt ar citiem.
mt: After that there are several medium-sized cats that eat medium-sized prey, from rabbits to antelopes and sheep. Finally, there are many small cats (including domestic cats), which eat much more various small prey, such as insects, rodents, grasshoppers and birds. Their secret is the niche concept - a special task that each cat performs and which does not allow it to compete with others.
ref: Under them are more medium sized cats that eat medium sized prey ranging from rabbits to antelopes and deer. Finally, there are many small cats (including loose pet cats) that eat the far more numerous small prey like insects, rodents, lizards, and birds. The secret to their success is the concept of the niche, a special job each cat holds that keeps it from competing with others.

src: Ocelotiem patīk ēst mazus dzīvniekus. Ja ir iespēja, viņi ķer pērtiķus, čūskas, grauzējus un putnus. Gandrīz visi dzīvnieki, kurus medī ocelots, ir daudz mazāki par viņu pašu. Zinātnieki domā, ka oceloti izseko un atrod dzīvniekus ēšanai (medījumu) pēc smaržas, ostot to uz zemes atstātās pēdas. Viņi var ļoti labi redzēt tumsā ar nakts redzes spēju un arī ļoti zagšus pārvietoties. Oceloti medī savu laupījumu, saplūstot ar apkārtni, pēc tam metoties virsū laupījumam.
mt: Ocelots like to eat small animals. If they have the chance, they will catch rabbits, snakes, rodents and birds. Almost all animals that ocelots hunt are much smaller than themselves. Scientists think that ocelots follow and find animals to eat (prey) by smell, tracking them by the footprints they leave on the ground. They can see very well in the dark with their night vision and also move very quietly. Ocelots hunt their prey by blending in with their surroundings, then pouncing on the prey.
ref: Ocelots like to eat small animals. They will catch monkeys, snakes, rodents and birds if they can. Almost all of the animals that the ocelot hunts are far smaller than it is. Scientists think that ocelots follow and find animals to eat (prey) by smell, sniffing for where they've been on the ground. They can see very well in the dark with night vision, and move very stealthily, too. Ocelots hunt their prey by blending in with their surroundings then pouncing on their prey.

src: Atlētiskais tīģeris spēj rāpties (lai gan ne pārāk labi), peldēt, veikt garus lēcienus un vilkt ar piecreiz lielāku spēku nekā spēcīgs cilvēks. Tīģeris ir tajā pašā grupā (panteru ģints), kur lauvas, leopardi un jaguāri. Šie četri kaķi ir vienīgie, kas var rēkt. Tīģera rēciens nav līdzīgs lauvas pilnās balss rēcienam, bet drīzāk kā ņurdošu, izkliegtu vārdu teikums.
mt: The athletic tiger can run (albeit not very well), swim, leap, and pull with a force nine times that of a man. The tiger is in the same group (Panthera genus) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These four cats are the only ones that can roar. A tiger's roar is not like a lion's full-throated roar, but rather a sort of muffled, slurred word.
ref: A well rounded athlete, the tiger can climb (though not well), swim, leap great distances and pull with five times the force of a strong human. The tiger is in the same group (Genus Panthera) as lions, leopards, and jaguars. These four cats are the only ones who can roar. The tiger's roar is not like the full-voiced roar of a lion, but more like a sentence of snarly, shouted words.

src: Šūna ir dzīva organisma (dzīvu lietu) vismazākā strukturālā un funkcionālā vienība. Šūna ir cēlusies no latīņu vārda 'cella', kas nozīmē mazu telpu. Ja paskatīsieties uz dzīvām būtnēm zem mikroskopa, ievērosiet, ka tās sastāv no nelieliem kvadrātiņiem vai lodītēm. Roberts Huks, dabaszinātnieks no Anglijas, ar mikroskopu korķī novēroja mazus kvadrātiņus. Tās izskatījās kā telpas. Viņš bija pirmais cilvēks, kurš novēroja mirušās šūnas
mt: A cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of an organism. It is the smallest unit of life that can replicate independently, and is often referred to as the building block of life. The word cell comes from the Latin cellula, meaning "small room", which in turn comes from the Latin word celare, meaning "to hide". The French zoologist and botanist Adrien-Henri de Jussieu first used the term "cellule" in 1824, to describe the smallest living units in the organisms that he studied. The word cell was used in English in 1831 by botanist Thomas Andrew Knight, and later in 1835 by botanist John Lindley. The term "cell theory" (Anatomisch-Zellentheorie) was coined by German zoologist Heinrich Wilhelm Gottfried von Waldeyer in 1886.
ref: A cell is the smallest structural and functional unit of a living (things) organism. Cell comes from the Latin word cella which means small room. If you look at living things under a microscope, you will see that they are made of small squares or balls. Robert Hooke, a biologist from England, saw small squares in cork with a microscope. They looked like rooms. He was the first person to observe dead cells

src: Dzīvnieku ķermenis sastāv no daudz šūnām. Tie ēd dažādus produktus un pārstrādā tos savā organismā. Vairums dzīvnieku spēj kustēties. Smadzenes ir tikai dzīvniekiem (lai gan pat ne visiem dzīvniekiem; piemēram, medūzām nav smadzeņu). Dzīvnieki apdzīvo visu Zemeslodi. Tie rok alas, peld okeānos un lido gaisā.
mt: An animal body is made up of many cells. They eat different products and process them in their organism. Most animals can move. Brains are only in animals (although not all animals; for example, jellyfish do not have brains). Animals inhabit all the continents. They dig holes, swim in oceans and fly in the air.
ref: Animals are made of many cells. They eat things and digest them inside. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (though not even all animals do; jellyfish, for example, do not have brains). Animals are found all over the earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky.

src: Augi ražo skābekli, ko cilvēki elpo, bet uzņem oglekļa dioksīdu, kuru cilvēki izelpo. Augi savas barības vielas uzņem no saules, izmantojot fotosintēzi. Tie arī nodrošina ēnu. Mēs veidojam savas mājas no augiem un izgatavojam drēbes no augiem. Lielākā daļa pārtikas, ko mēs ēdam, ir augi. Bez augiem dzīvnieki nevarētu izdzīvot.
mt: Plants produce oxygen, which humans breathe, but take in carbon dioxide, which humans exhale. Plants take in their food from the sun using photosynthesis. We build our homes from plants and make clothes from plants. Most of the food we eat is plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.
ref: Plants make oxygen which humans breathe, and they take in carbon-dioxide which humans exhale (that is, breathe out). Plants make their food from the sun by photosynthesis. They also provide shade. We make our houses from plants and make clothes from plants. Most foods that we eat are plants. Without plants, animals could not survive.

src: Kad neliela dzīvo būtņu grupa (maza populācija) tiek atdalīta no galvenās populācijas, no kuras nākusi (piemēram, ja viņi pārvietojas pa kalnu grēdu vai upi vai pārceļas uz jaunu salu, lai nevarētu tik viegli pārcelties atpakaļ), viņi bieži nonāks citā vidē, nevis tajā, kurā viņi bija agrāk. Šai jaunajai videi ir atšķirīgi resursi un dažādi konkurenti, tāpēc jaunajai populācijai būs nepieciešamas atšķirīgas iezīmes vai pielāgojumi, lai viņi būtu spēcīgāki konkurenti nekā viņiem vajadzēja būt iepriekš. Sākotnējā populācija nemaz nav mainījusies, viņiem joprojām ir vajadzīga tāda pati pielāgošanās kā iepriekš. Laika gaitā, jaunajiem iedzīvotājiem sākot pielāgoties savai jaunajai videi, tie kļūst arvien mazāk līdzīgi pārējiem iedzīvotājiem. Galu galā pēc tūkstošiem vai miljoniem gadu abas populācijas izskatīsies tik atšķirīgas, ka tās nevarēs saukt par vienu sugu. Mēs šo procesu saucam par speciāciju, kas tikai nozīmē jaunu sugu veidošanos. Speciācija ir neizbēgamas sekas un ļoti svarīga evolūcijas sastāvdaļa.
mt: When a small group (subpopulation) is separated from the main population from which it came (for example, if they move across a mountain ridge or river or migrate to a new island, so they can't easily move back), they often end up in a different environment, not the one they were in before. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population will need different traits or adaptations to be better competitors than they were before. The original population has not changed, they still need the same adaptations as before. Over time, as the new inhabitants start adapting to their new environment, they become less and less like the other inhabitants. Eventually, after thousands or millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they can't be called the same species. We call this process speciation, which just means the creation of a new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and a very important part of evolution.
ref: When a small group of living things (a small population) gets separated from the main population that they came from (like if they move over a mountain range or a river, or if they move to a new island so that they can't easily move back) they will often find themselves in a different environment than they were in before. This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so the new population will need different features or adaptations to be a strong competitor than what they had needed before. The original population hasn't changed at all, they still need the same adaptations as before. Over time, as the new population begins to adapt to their new environment, they start to look less and less like the other population. Eventually, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they can't be called the same species. We call this process speciation, which just means the formation of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

src: Asinsrites sistēmas galvenais orgāns ir sirds, kas sūknē asinis. Asins aizplūst no sirds pa asinsvadiem, ko sauc par artērijām, un atgriežas uz sirdi pa asinsvadiem, ko sauc par vēnām. Vismazākos asinsvadus sauc par kapilāriem.
mt: The heart is the main organ of the circulatory system. Blood flows out of the heart through arteries, and returns to the heart through veins. The smallest blood vessels are called capillaries.
ref: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps the blood. Blood goes away from the heart in tubes called arteries and comes back to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.

src: Asinsrites sistēmas galvenais orgāns ir sirds, kas sūknē asinis. Asins aizplūst no sirds pa asinsvadiem, ko sauc par artērijām, un atgriežas uz sirdi pa asinsvadiem, ko sauc par vēnām. Vismazākos asinsvadus sauc par kapilāriem.
mt: The heart is the main organ of the circulatory system. Blood flows out of the heart through arteries, and returns to the heart through veins. The smallest blood vessels are called capillaries.
ref: The major organ of the circulatory system is the heart, which pumps the blood. Blood goes away from the heart in tubes called arteries and comes back to the heart in tubes called veins. The smallest tubes are called capillaries.

src: Insekti bija pirmie dzīvnieki, kuri pacēlās gaisā. Viņu spēja lidot palīdzēja vieglāk izvairīties no ienaidniekiem, kā arī efektīvāk atrast barību un partneri. Vairākumam kukaiņu ir tāda priekšrocība, ka tie spēj salocīt spārnus uz aizmuguri, piekļaujot tos ķermenim visā garumā. Tas viņiem dod plašāku nelielo vietu klāstu, kur paslēpties no plēsējiem. Mūsdienās vienīgie kukaiņi, kas nevar atlocīt savus spārnus, ir dažādspārnu spāres un viendienītes.
mt: Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly helped them avoid predators, and find food and mates more effectively. Most insects have the advantage of being able to tuck their wings along their body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, only butterflies and moths cannot tuck their wings.
ref: Insects were the first animals to take to the air. Their ability to fly helped them evade enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back along the body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold back their wings are dragon flies and mayflies.

src: Insekti bija pirmie dzīvnieki, kuri pacēlās gaisā. Viņu spēja lidot palīdzēja vieglāk izvairīties no ienaidniekiem, kā arī efektīvāk atrast barību un partneri. Vairākumam kukaiņu ir tāda priekšrocība, ka tie spēj salocīt spārnus uz aizmuguri, piekļaujot tos ķermenim visā garumā. Tas viņiem dod plašāku nelielo vietu klāstu, kur paslēpties no plēsējiem. Mūsdienās vienīgie kukaiņi, kas nevar atlocīt savus spārnus, ir dažādspārnu spāres un viendienītes.
mt: Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly helped them avoid predators, and find food and mates more effectively. Most insects have the advantage of being able to tuck their wings along their body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, only butterflies and moths cannot tuck their wings.
ref: Insects were the first animals to take to the air. Their ability to fly helped them evade enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently. Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back along the body. This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators. Today, the only insects that cannot fold back their wings are dragon flies and mayflies.

src: Mūsdienās daudzi paleontologi uzskata, ka viena dinozauru grupa izdzīvoja un dzīvo vēl tagad. Mēs tos saucam par putniem. Daudzi cilvēki tos neuztver kā dinozaurus, jo tiem ir spalvas un tie prot lidot. Taču putniem joprojām ir daudzas īpašības, kas atgādina dinozauru. Viņiem ir kājas ar zvīņām un nagiem, viņi dēj olas un staigā uz abām savām aizmugurējām kājām kā tiranozaurs.
mt: Today many paleontologists believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and still lives today. We call them birds. Many people do not consider them dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But birds still have many characteristics that resemble dinosaurs. They have legs with claws and nails, they lay eggs and walk on their hind legs like a tyrannosaur.
ref: Many paleontologists today believe that one group of dinosaurs survived and is alive today. We call them birds. Many people don't think about them as dinosaurs because they have feathers and can fly. But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like a dinosaur. They have feet with scales and claws, they lay eggs, and they walk on their two back legs like a T-Rex.

src: Triceratopu zobi varēja sagrauzt ne tikai lapas, bet arī ļoti cietus zarus un saknes. Daži zinātnieki uzskata, ka triceratopsi ēda palmpapardes — krīta periodā izplatītu augu. Šie augi izskatās kā maza palma ar asu, smaiļotu lapu vainagu. Triceratops, iespējams, izmantoja savu spēcīgo knābi, lai notrauktu lapas pirms stumbra apēšanas. Citi zinātnieki iebilst, ka šie augi ir ļoti indīgi, tāpēc ir maz ticams, ka dinozauri būtu tos ēduši, tomēr mūsdienās sliņķi un citi dzīvnieki, piemēram, papagaiļi (dinozauru pēcteči), var ēst indīgas lapas vai augļus.
mt: Triceratops teeth could have crushed not only leaves, but also very hard twigs and roots. Some scientists believe that triceratops ate palm fronds — a widespread plant of the Cretaceous period. These plants look like a small palm with a sharp, serrated leafy vane. Triceratops may have used its powerful beak to strip leaves before swallowing the stem. Other scientists object that these plants are very poisonous, so it is unlikely that the dinosaurs would have eaten them, but modern squirrels and other animals, such as parrots (dinosaur descendants), can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.
ref: A triceratops' teeth would have been able to crush not only leaves but even very tough branches and roots. Some scientists think Triceratops ate cycads, which are a type of plant that was common in the Cretaceous. These plants look like a small palm tree with a crown of sharp, spiky leaves. A Triceratops could have used its strong beak to strip off the leaves before eating the trunk. Other scientists argue that these plants are very poisonous so it is unlikely that any dinosaur ate them, even though today the sloth and other animals like the parrot (a descendant of the dinosaurs) can eat poisonous leaves or fruit.

src: Itālijas futbola izlase, kā arī Vācijas futbola izlase ir otra veiksmīgāka komanda visā pasaulē, kura ir arī izcīnījusi 2006. gada FIFA Pasaules kausu. Populārākie sporta veidi ir futbols, basketbols, volejbols, ūdenspolo, paukošana, regbijs, riteņbraukšana, ledus hokejs, skrituļhokejs un F1 autosacīkstes. Ziemas sporta veidi ir vispopulārākie ziemeļu reģionos, un itāļi sacenšas gan starptautiskajās, gan olimpiskajās spēlēs.
mt: Italy's national football team, as well as Germany's national football team, is the most successful team in the world, having also won the 2006 FIFA World Cup. Popular sports include football, basketball, volleyball, water polo, fencing, rugby, cycling, ice hockey, speed skating and Formula One. Winter sports are the most popular in the northern regions, and Italians compete in both international and Olympic games.
ref: Italy's national football, along with German national football team is the second most successful team in the world and were the FIFA World Cup champions in 2006. Popular sports include football, basketball, volleyball, water-polo, fencing, rugby, cycling, ice hockey, roller hockey and F1 motor racing. Winter sports are most popular in the Northern regions, with Italians competing in international games and Olympic events.

src: Luksemburgai ir sena vēsture, taču tā pasludināja savu neatkarību 1839. gadā. Beļģijas tagadējās daļas senāk piederēja Luksemburgai, taču tika pievienotas Beļģijai pēc 1830. gadu revolūcijas. Luksemburga vienmēr ir mēģinājusi saglabāt neitrālas valsts statusu, taču Vācija to okupēja gan Pirmajā, gan Otrajā pasaules karā. 1957. gadā Luksemburga kļuva par vienu no tās organizācijas dibinātājām, kas šodien tiek saukta par Eiropas Savienību.
mt: Luxembourg has a long history, but declared its independence in 1839. The parts of today's Belgium were once part of Luxembourg, but were added to Belgium after the 1830s revolution. Luxembourg has always tried to maintain a neutral state, but was occupied by Germany in both World Wars. In 1957, Luxembourg became one of the founding members of the organization that is now called the European Union.
ref: Luxembourg has a long history but its independence dates from 1839. Present-day parts of Belgium were part of Luxembourg in the past but became Belgian after the 1830s Belgian Revolution. Luxembourg has always tried to remain a neutral country but it was occupied in both World War I and World War II by Germany. In 1957 Luxembourg became a founding member of the organization which is today known as the European Union.

src: Turcijas Eiropas daļa (Austrumtrāķija jeb Rumēlija Balkānu pussalā) ietver 3% no valsts teritorijas. Turcijas teritorija ir vairāk nekā 1600 kilometrus (1000 jūdzes) gara un 800 km (500 jūdzes) plata, tai ir taisnstūrim līdzīga forma. Turcijas platība, ieskaitot ezerus, aizņem 783 562 kvadrātkilometrus (300 948 kv. jūdzes), no kuriem 755 688 kvadrātkilometri (291 773 kv. jūdzes) atrodas Āzijas dienvidrietumos un 23 764 kvadrātkilometri (9174 kv. jūdzes) Eiropā. Turcija teritorijas platības ziņā ir 37. lielākā valsts pasaulē, un tās platība ir līdzīga metropoles Francijas un Lielbritānijas teritoriju summai. Turciju no trim pusēm ieskauj jūras: Egejas jūra rietumos, Melnā jūra ziemeļos un Vidusjūra dienvidos.
mt: 3% of Turkey is in Europe (Eastern Thrace in the Balkan Peninsula). Turkey is a transcontinental country, with 97.8% of its territory in Asia and 2.2% in Europe. The country is bordered by eight countries: Bulgaria to the northwest; Greece to the west; Georgia to the northeast; Armenia, Iran and Iraq to the east; and Syria and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. The country is connected to Europe through the Bosphorus strait, the Sea of Marmara, and the Dardanelles strait, and is connected to Asia through the Bosphorus strait and the Sea of Marmara. Turkey is the world's 5th largest country in terms of population and the 37th largest country in terms of area.
ref: European Turkey (eastern Thrace or Rumelia in the Balkan peninsula) includes 3% of the country. The territory of Turkey is more than 1,600 kilometres (1,000 mi) long and 800 km (500 mi) wide, with a roughly rectangular shape. Turkey's area, including lakes, occupies 783,562 square kilometres (300,948 sq mi), of which 755,688 square kilometres (291,773 sq mi) are in south west Asia and 23,764 square kilometres (9,174 sq mi) in Europe. Turkey's area makes it the world's 37th-largest country, and is about the size of Metropolitan France and the United Kingdom combined. Turkey is encircled by seas on three sides: the Aegean Sea to the west, the Black Sea to the north and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.

src: Vatikāna iedzīvotāju skaits ir ap 800. Tā ir mazākā neatkarīgā valsts pasaulē un valsts ar vismazāko iedzīvotāju skaitu. Vatikāns savā likumdošanā un oficiālajā saziņā izmanto itāļu valodu. Itāļu valoda ir arī ikdienas valoda, ko izmanto lielākā daļa šajā valstī strādājošo, bet latīņu valoda bieži tiek izmantota reliģiskās ceremonijās. Visi Vatikāna iedzīvotāji ir Romas katoļi.
mt: 800 people live in the Vatican, the smallest independent state in the world and the state with the smallest population. Italian is used in the Vatican's legislation and official communications. Italian is also the everyday language used by most of the people working in the Vatican, but Latin is often used in religious ceremonies. All the people living in the Vatican are Roman Catholics.
ref: Vatican City's population is around 800. It is the smallest independent country in the world and the country with the lowest population. Vatican City uses Italian in its legislation and official communications. Italian is also the everyday language used by most of those who work in the state while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies. All citizens of Vatican City are Roman Catholic.

src: Mūsdienās datorus izmanto attēlu un video apstrādei. Sarežģītas animācijas var izveidot datoros, un šāda veida animācija arvien vairāk tiek izmantota televīzijā un filmās. Mūzika nereti tiek ierakstīta, izmantojot sarežģītus datorus, kuros skaņa tiek apstrādāta un miksēta kopā.
mt: Today computers are used for image and video processing. Complex animations can be created on computers, and such animation is increasingly used in television and movies. Music is often recorded using complex computers, where sound is processed and mixed together.
ref: Computers today are used to manipulate pictures and videos. Sophisticated animations can be constructed on computers, and this kind of animation is increasingly being used in television and films. Music is often recorded using sophisticated computers to process and mix sounds together.

src: Harapas un Mohendžodaro pilsētās gandrīz katrā mājā bija ūdensklozeta tualete, kas bija piesaistīta sarežģītai kanalizācijas sistēmai. Notekūdeņu sistēmu atliekas ir atrastas Mīnojas (Krēta) pilsētu un Santorini (Grieķija) salas mājās. Tualetes bija arī Senajā Ēģiptē, Persijā un Ķīnā. Romas civilizācijā tualetes reizēm bija daļa no sabiedriskajām pirtīm, kur vīrieši un sievietes gāja kopā jauktā sabiedrībā.
mt: In almost every house in Harappa and Mohenjo-daro were water closet toilets connected to a complex sewage system. Sewage systems have been found in Minoan (Crete) and Santorini (Greece) houses. Toilets were also used in Ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In the Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public baths, where men and women went together in mixed company.
ref: The cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-daro had a flush toilet in almost every house, attached to a sophisticated sewage system. Remains of sewage systems have been found in the houses of the Minoan cities of Crete and Santorini in Greece. There were also toilets in ancient Egypt, Persia and China. In Roman civilization, toilets were sometimes part of public bath houses where men and women were together in mixed company.

src: Mūsdienu ledus slidu asmenim ir divkārša mala ar ieliektu iedobumu starp tām. Divas malas ļauj labāk izveidot saķeri ar ledu pat tad, kad tās ir sasvērtā pozīcijā. Tā ka slieces apakšējā daļa ir nedaudz izliekta, tai paliecoties uz vienu vai otru pusi, izliecas arī tā mala, kura ir saskarē ar ledu. Tas liek slidotājam pagriezties. Ja slidas sasveras pa labi, slidotājs pagriežas pa labi, ja slidas sasveras uz kreiso pusi, tad slidotājs pagriežas pa kreisi.
mt: 21st century ice skates have a double blade with a concave groove between them. Two blades allow better carving with the ice when they are in a set position. The lower part of the blade is slightly concave, so when it is in contact with the ice, the blade also concaves to the side it is in contact with. This causes the skater to turn. If the skates are set to the right, the skater turns to the right, if the skates are set to the left, the skater turns to the left.
ref: The blade on a modern ice skate has a double edge with a concave hollow between them. The two edges allow for a better grasp of the ice, even when tilted. Because the bottom of the blade is slightly curved, as the blade tilts to one side or the other, the edge which is in contact with the ice also curves. This causes the skater to turn. If the skates tilt to the right, the skater turns right, if the skates tilt to the left, the skater turns left.

src: "Lai atgrieztos savā iepriekšējā enerģijas līmenī, viņiem ir jāatbrīvojas no papildu enerģijas, kuru tie saņēma no gaismas. Tie to dara, izstarojot niecīgu gaismas daļiņu, ko sauc par ""fotonu"". Zinātnieki šo procesu sauc par ""stimulētu starojuma emisiju"", jo spožā gaisma stimulē atomus, izraisot gaismas fotona emisiju, un gaisma ir starojuma veids. Nākamajā attēlā redzami atomi, kas izstaro fotonus. Protams, patiesībā fotoni ir daudz mazāki nekā attēlā redzamie. Fotoni ir vēl mazāki nekā vielas, no kā uzbūvēti atomi!"
mt: "To return to their previous energy level, they must release excess energy they gained from light. They do this by emitting a tiny amount of light called a "photon." Scientists call this "stimulated emission" because bright light stimulates atoms to emit photons, and light is a form of stimulation. The atoms are shown emitting photons in the next image. Of course, photons are much smaller than the atoms they are emitted from. Photons are even smaller than the atoms they are emitted from."
ref: "To return to their previous energy level, they must get rid of the extra energy they got from the light. They do this by emitting a tiny particle of light called a ""photon"". Scientists call this process ""stimulated emission of radiation"" because the atoms are stimulated by the bright light, causing the emission of a photon of light, and light is a type of radiation. The next picture shows the atoms emitting photons. Of course, in reality photons are a lot smaller than those in the picture. Photons are even smaller than the stuff that makes up atoms!"

src: "Lai atgrieztos savā iepriekšējā enerģijas līmenī, viņiem ir jāatbrīvojas no papildu enerģijas, kuru tie saņēma no gaismas. Tie to dara, izstarojot niecīgu gaismas daļiņu, ko sauc par ""fotonu"". Zinātnieki šo procesu sauc par ""stimulētu starojuma emisiju"", jo spožā gaisma stimulē atomus, izraisot gaismas fotona emisiju, un gaisma ir starojuma veids. Nākamajā attēlā redzami atomi, kas izstaro fotonus. Protams, patiesībā fotoni ir daudz mazāki nekā attēlā redzamie. Fotoni ir vēl mazāki nekā vielas, no kā uzbūvēti atomi!"

Scientists call this "stimulated emission" because bright light stimulates atoms to emit photons, and light is a form of stimulation. The atoms are shown emitting photons in the next image. Of course, photons are much smaller than the atoms they are emitted from. Photons are even smaller than the atoms they are emitted from."

Scientists call this process ""stimulated emission of radiation"" because the atoms are stimulated by the bright light, causing the emission of a photon of light, and light is a type of radiation. The next picture shows the atoms emitting photons. Of course, in reality photons are a lot smaller than those in the picture. Photons are even smaller than the stuff that makes up atoms!"

src: Pēc simtiem stundu ilgas darbības spuldzes kvēldiegs beigu beigās izdeg un spuldze vairs nedarbojas. Pēc tam spuldze ir jānomaina. Nomainot spuldzi, jābūt uzmanīgam. Pirmkārt, gaismas ķermeņa slēdzim jābūt izslēgtam vai jāatvieno kabelis. Tas ir tāpēc, ka elektrība, kas ieplūst kontaktligzdā, kur atrodas spuldzes metāla daļa, var izraisīt smagu elektrošoku, ja pieskaraties kontaktligzdas iekšpusei vai spuldzes metāla pamatnei, kamēr tā joprojām daļēji ir kontaktligzdā.
mt: After hundreds of hours of operation, the light bulb's filament burns out and the bulb no longer works. To replace the bulb, be careful. First, the light fixture's switch must be turned off or the cord disconnected. This is because the electricity that enters the contact socket, where the metal part of the bulb is located, can cause a serious electric shock if you touch the inside of the contact socket or the metal base of the bulb while it is still partially in the contact socket.
ref: After hundreds of hours of operation the filament in the bulb eventually burns out and the light bulb no longer works. The light bulb then needs replacing. It is necessary to be careful in replacing the light bulb. First, the switch for the light fixture needs to be turned off or the cable disconnected. This is because electricity flowing into the socket where the metallic part of bulb sits can give you a severe electric shock if you touch the inside of the socket or the metal base of the bulb while it is still partly in the socket.

src: Atombumba darbojas pēc principa, ka ir vajadzīga enerģija, lai saliktu kodolu ar daudziem protoniem un neitroniem. Savā ziņā kā kalnā ripinot smagus ratus. Atkal sadalot kodolu, daļa šīs enerģijas tiek atbrīvota. Dažiem atomiem ir nestabili kodoli, un tas nozīmē, ka tiem ir tendence dalīties ar nelielu pamudinājumu vai vienkārši tāpat.
mt: The atomic bomb works on the principle that energy is needed to split a nucleus with many protons and neutrons. Like a mountain ripping apart heavy rocks. Again splitting the nucleus, some of this energy is released. Some atoms have unstable nuclei, meaning they have a tendency to split with little provocation or just like that.
ref: The fission bomb works on the principle that it takes energy to put together a nucleus with many protons and neutrons. Sort of like rolling a heavy cart up a hill. Splitting the nucleus up again then releases some of that energy. Some atoms have unstable nuclei which means that they tend to break apart with little or no nudging.

src: Zvanot kādam, kurš atrodas vairāku tūkstošu jūdžu attālumā, jūs izmantojat satelītu. Kosmosā satelīts saņem zvanu un pēc tam gandrīz uzreiz atspoguļo to atpakaļ. Satelītu kosmosā nosūtīja raķete. Zinātnieki kosmosā izmanto teleskopus, jo Zemes atmosfēra sagroza daļu no mūsu gaismas un skata. Lai palaistu kosmosā satelītu vai teleskopu, ir nepieciešama milzīga raķete, kuras augstums pārsniedz 100 pēdas.
mt: To call someone who is thousands of miles away, you use a satellite. The satellite receives the call and almost immediately reflects it back. The satellite was launched into space by a rocket. Scientists use telescopes in space because Earth's atmosphere absorbs some of our light and view. To launch a satellite or telescope into space, you need a huge rocket whose height exceeds 100 feet.
ref: When you call someone who is thousands of miles away, you are using a satellite. The satellite in space gets the call and then reflects it back down, almost instantly. The satellite was sent into space by a rocket. Scientists use telescopes in space because the Earth’s atmosphere distorts some of our light and view. It takes a giant rocket over a 100 feet high to put a satellite or telescope in space.

src: Laiks ir kas tāds, kas atrodas mums visapkārt un ietekmē visu, ko darām, tomēr to ir grūti izprast. Vairākus tūkstošus gadu laiku ir pētījuši reliģiozie, filozofiskie un zinātniskie pētnieki. Mēs izdzīvojam laiku kā notikumu virkni, kas no nākotnes ved caur tagadni un tad uz pagātni. Laiks ir arī tas, kā mēs salīdzinām notikumu ilgumu (garumu). Konstatēt to, ka laiks iet, varat pats, novērojot ciklisku notikumu atkārtošanos. Ciklisks notikums ir tāds notikums, kas regulāri atkārtojas.
mt: Time is something that surrounds us and influences everything we do, but it is hard to understand. For thousands of years, religious, philosophical and scientific researchers have studied time. We survive time as a sequence of events that leads from the future through the present and then to the past. Time is also how we compare the duration of events. You can observe the cyclical repetition of events yourself, by noticing the cyclical recurrence of events. A cyclical event is an event that recurs regularly.
ref: Time is something that is all around us, and affects everything we do, yet is difficult to understand. Time has been studied by religious, philosophical, and scientific scholars for thousands of years. We experience time as a series of events passing from the future through the present to the past. Time is also how we compare the duration (length) of events. You can mark the passing of time yourself by observing the repetition of a cyclical event. A cyclical event is something that happens again and again regularly.

src: Tradicionāli troņmantnieks uzreiz pēc skolas beigšanas dodas militārajos spēkos. Tomēr Čārlzs ieguva augstāko izglītību Trinity koledžā Kembridžā, kur viņš studēja antropoloģiju un arheoloģiju, bet vēlāk vēsturi, saņemot galīgo novērtējumu 2:2 (zemākā otrās klases pakāpe). Čārlzs bija pirmais britu karaliskās ģimenes loceklis, kurš saņēma akadēmisko grādu.
mt: Traditionally, the heir to the throne immediately after leaving school joins the military. However, Charles received higher education at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he studied anthropology and archaeology, but later history, receiving a final assessment of 2:2 (lower second class). Charles was the first member of the royal family to receive an academic degree.
ref: Traditionally, the heir to the throne would go straight into the military after finishing school. However, Charles went to university at Trinity College, Cambridge where he studied Anthropology and Archaeology, and later History, earning a 2:2 (a lower second class degree). Charles was the first member of the British Royal Family to be awarded a degree.

src: Anglija bija baudījusi ilgstošu miera periodu pēc dāņu varas atjaunošanas. Tomēr 991. gadā Etelreds satapās ar vikingu floti, kas bija lielāka nekā jebkura flote kopš Gutruma flotes pirms simts gadiem. Šo floti vadīja Olafs Trigvasons - norvēģis ar ambīcijām atgūt savu valsti no Dānijas kundzības. Pēc sākotnējām militārajām neveiksmēm Eselreds beidzot panāca vienošanos ar Olafu, kurš atgriezās no Norvēģijas, lai mēģinātu atgūt savu karaļvalsti, kas mijās ar dažādiem panākumiem.
mt: 991 AD: England had enjoyed a long period of peace after the restoration of Danish rule. However, in 991 AD Ethelred was alarmed by a Viking fleet, which was larger than any fleet since Guthrum's fleet a hundred years before. This fleet was led by Olaf Tryggvason - a Norwegian with ambitions to regain his kingdom from Danish rule. After initial military failures Ethelred finally reached an agreement with Olaf, who returned from Norway to try to regain his kingdom, which was mixed with varying degrees of success.
ref: England had experienced a long period of peace after the reconquest of the Danelaw. However in 991 Ethelred was faced with a Viking fleet larger than any since Guthrum's a century earlier. This fleet was led by Olaf Trygvasson, a Norwegian with ambitions to reclaim his country from Danish domination. After initial military setbacks, Ethelred was able to agree to terms with Olaf, who returned to Norway to try to gain his kingdom with mixed success.

src: "Ap 15. gadsimtu Igaunijas ziemeļdaļas kultūru lielā mērā ietekmēja Vācija. Daži vācu mūki vēlējās vest Dievu tuvāk vietējiem iedzīvotājiem, tāpēc izgudroja igauņu literāro valodu. Tā pamatā tika izmantots vācu valodas alfabēts, kam tika pievienota viena rakstzīme ""Õ/õ"". Laika gaitā daudzi no vācu valodas aizgūtie vārdi iedzīvojās. Tas bija apgaismības laikmeta sākums."
mt: 15th century, the culture of northern Estonia was largely influenced by Germany. Some German monks wanted to bring God closer to the local population, so they invented the Estonian literary language. Its basis was the German alphabet, to which one letter "Õ/õ" was added. Over time, many words from the German language were assimilated. This was the beginning of the era of enlightenment.
ref: "Around the 15th century, northern Estonia was under great cultural influence of Germany. Some German monks wanted to bring God closer to the native people, so they invented the Estonian literal language. It was based on the German alphabet and one character ""Õ/õ"" was added. As time passed, many words that were borrowed from German coalesced. This was the beginning of enlightenment."

src: Ir dažādi aprēķini par to, cik cilvēku runā hindi valodā. Tiek lēsts, ka tā ir starp otro un ceturto visbiežāk runāto valodu pasaulē. Dzimtajā valodā runājošo skaits mainās atkarībā no tā, vai tiek ieskaitīti ļoti cieši radniecīgie dialekti. Tiek lēsts, ka šajā valodā runā 340–500 miljoni cilvēku, kā arī to saprotu vismaz 800 miljoni cilvēku. Hindi un urdu ir līdzīgs vārdu krājums, bet dažāda rakstība; ikdienas sarunās abu valodu pārstāvji parasti var saprast viens otru.
mt: There are various estimates of the number of people who speak Hindi. It is estimated to be the third or fourth most spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers varies depending on whether closely related dialects are included. It is estimated that 340–500 million people speak Hindi, and at least 800 million people understand it. Hindi and Urdu have a similar vocabulary, but different writing systems; speakers of both languages can usually understand each other.
ref: There are varying estimates for how many people speak Hindi. It is estimated to be between the second and fourth most commonly spoken language in the world. The number of native speakers varies depending on whether or not very closely related dialects are counted. Estimates range from 340 million to 500 million speakers, and as many as 800 million people can understand the language. Hindi and Urdu are similar in vocabulary but different in script; in everyday conversations, speakers of both languages can usually understand each other.

src: "Hangils ir vienīgais apzināti izveidotais alfabēts, ko plaši izmanto ikdienā. Alfabētu ieviesa 1444. gadā Karaļa Sedžonga valdīšanas laikā (1418.–1450. g.). Karalis Sejongs bija ceturtais Čosonu dinastijas karalis un ir viens no visaugstāk vērtētajiem karaļiem. Sākotnēji viņš nosauca hangila alfabētu par ""Hunmin Jeongeum"", kas nozīmē ""pareizas skaņas instrukciju došanai cilvēkiem""."
mt: "Hangul is the only alphabet created by a single person that is widely used in everyday life. The alphabet was introduced in 1444 by King Sejong, who ruled from 1418 to 1450. King Sejong was the fourth ruler of the Joseon Dynasty and is one of the most highly regarded kings. Initially, he called the Hangul alphabet ""Hunmin Jeongeum"", which means ""giving people the correct sounds"". "
ref: "Hangeul is the only purposely invented alphabet in popular daily use. The alphabet was invented in 1444 during the reign of King Sejong (1418 – 1450). King Sejong was the fourth king of the Joseon Dynasty and is one of the most highly regarded. He originally named the Hangeul alphabet Hunmin Jeongeum, which means ""the correct sounds for the instruction of the people""."

src: Ir daudz teoriju par to, kā radās sanskrits. Viena no tām ir par āriešu migrāciju no rietumiem uz Indiju, tādējādi atvedot savu valodu. Sanskrits ir sena valoda, un to var salīdzināt ar Eiropā lietoto latīņu valodu. Pasaulē agrākā zināmā grāmata tika uzrakstīta sanskritā. Pēc upanišadu apkopošanas sanskrits hierarhijas dēļ vienkārši izzuda. Sanskrits ir ļoti sarežģīta un bagāta valoda, kura kalpojusi par daudzu mūsdienu indiešu valodu izcelsmes avotu, tāpat kā latīņu valoda ir eiropiešu valodu, piemēram, franču un spāņu, izcelsmes avots.
mt: There are many theories about how Sanskrit came to be. One of them is that it was brought to India by Aryan migration from the west. Sanskrit is an old language, and can be compared to the Latin language used in Europe. The oldest known book was written in Sanskrit. After the Upanishads were collected, Sanskrit simply died out. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served as the source of many modern Indian languages, just as Latin is the source of European languages such as French and Spanish.
ref: There are many theories to how Sanskrit came into existence. One of them is about an Aryan migration from the west into India who brought their language with them. Sanskrit is an ancient language and is comparable to the Latin language spoken in Europe. The earliest known book in the world was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of Upanishads, Sanskrit just faded due to hierarchy. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served to be the source for many modern Indian languages, just like Latin is the source for European languages like French and Spanish.

Sanskrit is an ancient language and is comparable to the Latin language spoken in Europe. The earliest known book in the world was written in Sanskrit. After the compilation of Upanishads, Sanskrit just faded due to hierarchy. Sanskrit is a very complex and rich language, which has served to be the source for many modern Indian languages, just like Latin is the source for European languages like French and Spanish.

src: Kā Īo gravitācija mani ietekmētu? Ja tu stāvētu uz Īo virsmas, tu svērtu mazāk nekā uz Zemes. Cilvēks, kas uz Zemes sver 200 mārciņas (90 kg), uz Jo svērtu apmēram 36 mārciņas (16 kg). Līdz ar to gravitātes iedarbība uz cilvēku, protams, ir krietni mazāka.
mt: How would I be affected by Io's gravity? If you stood on Io's surface, you would weigh less than on Earth. A person who weighs 200 pounds (90 kilograms) on Earth would weigh about 36 pounds (16 kilograms) on Io. So the force of gravity on a person is much less.
ref: How would Io's gravity pull on me? If you stood on the surface of Io, you would weigh less than you do on Earth. A person who weighs 200 pounds (90kg) on Earth would weigh about 36 pounds (16kg) on Io. So the gravity, of course, pulls less on you.

src: Mēness virsmu veido akmeņi un putekļi. Mēness ārējo slāni sauc par garozu. Garoza tuvākajā pusē ir aptuveni 70 km bieza, bet tālākajā pusē - 100 km bieza. Tas ir plānāks zem bazalta līdzenuma un biezāks zem augstienēm. Tuvākajā pusē varētu būt vairāk Mēness jūru, jo garoza ir plānāka. Lavai bija vieglāk pacelties līdz virsmai.
mt: The moon's surface is made of rocks and dust. The outer layer is called the regolith. The regolith is about 70 km thick in the near side and 100 km thick in the far side. It is thinner under the basaltic plains and thicker under the highlands. There may be more lunar seas in the near side, as the regolith is thinner. It was easier for Lava to rise to the surface.
ref: The surface of the Moon is made of rocks and dust. The outer layer of the Moon is called the crust. The crust is about 70 km thick on the near side and 100 km thick on the far side. It is thinner under the maria and thicker under the highlands. There may be more maria on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for lava to rise up to the surface.

src: "Daudzi cilvēki sapņo par dienu, kad varēs aizceļot uz citu zvaigzni un izpētīt citas pasaules, dažus cilvēkus interesē kosmoss, bet daļa tic, ka uz citas planētas, iespējams, dzīvo citplanētieši vai citas dzīvības formas. Taču, ja tas arī kādreiz notiek, tad vairs ilgi neatkārtojas. Zvaigznes ir izkaisītas triljoniem jūdžu attālumā no ""kaimiņu"" zvaigznēm. Varbūt kādu dienu jūsu mazmazbērni nostāsies uz svešas pasaules un domās par tās senajiem priekštečiem..."
mt: "Many people dream of a day when they can take off to another star and explore other worlds, some people are interested in space, but some believe that there may be aliens or other life forms on other planets. But if this ever happens, it will not be repeated for a long time. Stars are separated by trillions of miles from the "neighbor" stars. Maybe one day your grandchildren will land on a foreign world and think about its ancient ancestors..."
ref: "Many people dream of the day when humans can travel to another star and explore other worlds, some people wonder what's out there some belive that aliens or other life may live on another plant. But, if this ever does happen probably won't happen for a very long time. The stars are so spread out that there are trillions of miles between stars that are ""neighbors"". Maybe one day, your great grandchildren will be standing atop an alien world wondering about their ancient ancestors?"

src: "Saulei nav tādas garozas kā Zemei, uz kuras jūs varētu stāvēt. Visa Saule ir veidota no gāzēm, uguns un plazmas. Virzoties tālāk prom no Saules centra, gāze kļūst retinākā. Ārējo daļu, ko mēs redzam, skatoties uz Sauli, sauc par fotosfēru, kas nozīmē ""gaismas lode""."
mt: "The sun does not have a surface like the earth, on which you can stand. The sun is made up of gases, fire and plasma. Moving farther away from the sun's center, the gas becomes less dense. The outer part, which we see looking at the sun, is called the photosphere, which means "light layer.""
ref: "The Sun doesn't have a crust like the Earth that you can stand on. The whole Sun is made out of gases, fire, and plasma. The gas becomes thinner as you go farther from the center of the Sun. The outer-part we see when we look at the Sun is called the photosphere, which means ""ball of light""."

src: Aptuveni trīs tūkstošus gadu vēlāk, 1610. gadā itāļu astronoms Galileo Galilejs ar teleskopa palīdzību novēroja, ka līdzīgi kā Mēnesim arī Venērai ir fāzes. Fāzes pastāv tāpēc, ka apgaismota tiek tikai tā Veneras (vai Mēness) puse, kas ir vērsta pret Sauli. Venēras fāzes apstiprināja Kopernika teoriju par to, ka planētas riņķo ap Sauli. Tad dažus gadus vēlāk, 1639. gadā, angļu astronoms vārdā Džeremijs Horokss novēroja Venēras tranzītu.
mt: 3,000 years later, in 1610, Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei observed with a telescope that Venus, like the Moon, has phases. Phases exist because only one side of Venus (or the Moon) is illuminated by the Sun. The phases of Venus confirmed Copernicus' theory that planets orbit the Sun. Then a few years later, in 1639, English astronomer Jeremiah Horrocks observed the transit of Venus.
ref: About three thousand years later, in 1610, Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei used a telescope to observe that Venus has phases, just as the moon does. Phases happen because only the side of Venus (or of the Moon) facing the Sun is lighted. The phases of Venus supported the theory of Copernicus that the planets go around the Sun. Then, a few years later in 1639, an English astronomer named Jeremiah Horrocks observed a transit of Venus.

src: Amazone ir otra garākā un vislielākā upe uz Zemes. Tā satur vairāk nekā 8 reizes lielāku ūdens daudzumu kā otra lielākā upe. Amazone ir arī visplatākā upe uz Zemes, dažviet sešas jūdzes plata. No Amazones ietek 20% no ūdens apjoma, kas ieplūst okeānos no visām pasaules upēm. Maģistrālā Amazone ir 6387 km (3980 jūdzes). Tā iegūst ūdeni no tūkstošiem mazāku upju.
mt: The Amazon is the second longest and largest river on Earth. It contains more than eight times the water of the second largest river. The Amazon is also the widest river on Earth, in some places six miles wide. Twenty percent of the water that flows into the oceans from all the rivers of the world comes from the Amazon. The main stem of the Amazon is 3,980 miles (6,387 km) long. It receives water from thousands of smaller rivers.
ref: The Amazon River is the second longest and the biggest river on Earth. It carries more than 8 times as much water as the second biggest river. The Amazon is also the widest river on Earth, at times six miles wide. A full 20 percent of the water that pours out of the planet's rivers into the oceans comes from the Amazon. The main Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles). It collects water from thousands of smaller rivers.

src: 18% venecuēliešu ir bezdarbnieki, un vairums nodarbināto ir iesaistīti ēnu ekonomikā. Divas trešdaļas strādājošo venecuēliešu strādā pakalpojumu nozarē, gandrīz ceturtā daļa strādā rūpniecībā un piektā daļa lauksaimniecībā. Venecuēlas svarīga nozare ir naftas ieguve, jo valsts ir neto eksportētājs, lai gan naftas rūpniecībā strādā tikai 1% iedzīvotāju.
mt: 18% of Venezuelans are unemployed, and most of the employed are in the informal economy. Two-thirds of working Venezuelans work in the service sector, almost a quarter in manufacturing, and a fifth in agriculture. Venezuela's main industry is oil production, as the country is a net exporter of oil, although only 1% of the population works in the oil industry.
ref: Eighteen percent of Venezuelans are unemployed, and most of those who are employed work in the informal economy. Two thirds of Venezuelans who work do so in the service sector, nearly a quarter work in industry and a fifth work in agriculture. An important industry for Venezuelans is oil, where the country is a net exporter, even though only one percent work in the oil industry.

src: Zvaigznes izdala gaismu un siltumu no enerģijas, kas rodas, ūdeņraža atomiem saplūstot (vai sakausējoties), tādējādi veidojot smagākus elementus. Zinātnieki strādā pie tāda reaktora izveides, kas varētu radīt enerģiju tādā pašā veidā. Tomēr šo problēmu ir ļoti grūti atrisināt, un paies daudzi gadi, līdz redzēsim uzbūvētus noderīgus kodoltermiskos reaktorus.
mt: Stars emit light and heat from the energy released when hydrogen atoms fuse (or burn), thus creating heavier elements. Scientists are working on building a reactor that could produce energy in the same way. However, this problem is very difficult to solve, and it will take many years before we see built useful nuclear reactors.
ref: Stars give off light and heat because of the energy made when hydrogen atoms are merged (or fused) together to form heavier elements. Scientists are working to create a reactor that can make energy in the same way. This, however, is a very hard problem to solve and will take many years before we see useful fusion reactors built.

src: Elementi un savienojumi var pāriet no viena stāvokļa otrā un palikt nemainīgi. Slāpeklim gāzveida stāvoklī joprojām ir tādas pašas īpašības kā šķidram slāpeklim. Šķidrā stāvoklī blīvums ir lielāks, bet molekulas joprojām ir tādas pašas. Vēl viens piemērs ir ūdens. Ūdens savienojumu veido divi ūdeņraža atomi un viens skābekļa atoms. Tam ir vienāda molekulārā struktūra gāzveida, šķidruma un cietā formā. Lai arī tā fizikālais stāvoklis var mainīties, tā ķīmiskais sastāvs paliek nemainīgs.
mt: Elements and compounds can change from one state to another and remain unchanged. Gaseous state of nitrogen still has the same properties as liquid nitrogen. The density is higher, but the molecules are still the same. Another example is water. Water is made of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. It has the same molecular structure in gaseous, liquid and solid form. Although its physical state can change, its chemical composition remains unchanged.
ref: Elements and compounds can move from one state to another and not change. Nitrogen as a gas still has the same properties as liquid nitrogen. The liquid state is denser but the molecules are still the same. Water is another example. The compound water is made up of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. It has the same molecular structure whether it is a gas, liquid, or solid. Although its physical state may change, its chemical state remains the same.

src: Revolūcijas kara laikā trīspadsmit valstis, pamatojoties uz Konfederācijas statūtiem, pirmo reizi izveidoja vāju centrālo valdību, kuras vienīgā sastāvdaļa bija Kongress. Kongress nebija varas uzlikt nodokļus, un, tā kā nepastāvēja nekāda nacionālā izpildvara vai tiesu vara, tas paļāvās valsts iestādēm, kuras bieži vien nevēlējās sadarboties, cerot, ka tās ieviesīs visus tā pieņemtos likumus. Tam arī nebija pilnvaru atcelt nodokļu tiesību aktus un tarifus starp valstīm. Lai panti varētu tikt grozīti, bija nepieciešama visu štatu vienbalsīga piekrišana, bet štati pret centrālo valdību izturējās tik vieglprātīgi, ka to pārstāvji bieži vien nebija ieradušies.
mt: 13 states, citing the Confederate Constitution, for the first time formed a weak central government, whose only component was Congress. Congress had no power to levy taxes, and, as there was no national executive or judiciary, it relied on state agencies, which often refused to cooperate, hoping that they would implement all the laws it passed. It also had no power to repeal tax treaties and tariffs between states. To amend the Constitution, the consent of all states was required, but the states against the central government were so accommodating that their representatives often did not show up.
ref: During the Revolutionary War, the thirteen states first formed a weak central government—with the Congress being its only component—under the Articles of Confederation. Congress lacked any power to impose taxes, and, because there was no national executive or judiciary, it relied on state authorities, who were often uncooperative, to enforce all its acts. It also had no authority to override tax laws and tariffs between states. The Articles required unanimous consent from all the states before they could be amended and states took the central government so lightly that their representatives were often absent.

src: "Ja esat skatījies filmu „Nacionālie dārgumi”, varat uzskatīt, ka dārgumu karte tika uzzīmēta Neatkarības deklarācijas otrā pusē. Tomēr tā nav patiesība. Lai gan dokumenta aizmugurē kaut kas ir rakstīts, tā nav dārgumu karte. Neatkarības deklarācijas aizmugurē ir rakstīti šādi vārdi: ""Oriģinālā Neatkarības deklarācija, datēta ar 1776. gada 4. jūliju."" Teksts ir redzams dokumenta apakšējā daļā apgriezts otrādi. Lai gan neviens droši nezina, kurš to ir rakstījis, ir zināms, ka šis lielais pergamenta dokuments (29¾ x 24½ collas) īsi pēc tā tapšanas tika sarullēts un noglabāts. Tā ka piezīme, visdrīzāk, ir pievienota vienkārši kā etiķete."
mt: "If you've seen the movie "National Treasures", you can think that the treasure map was drawn on the back of the Declaration of Independence. However, this is not true. Although something is written on the back of the document, it is not a treasure map. On the back of the Declaration of Independence is written: "Original Declaration of Independence, dated July 4, 1776." The text is visible on the bottom part of the document reversed. Although no one knows who wrote it, it is known that this large parchment document (29¾ x 24½ inches) was folded and stored shortly after its creation. As a note, it was probably just added as a sticker."
ref: "If you have watched the movie National Treasure, you may think a treasure map was written on the back of the Declaration of Independence. However, that is not true. Although there is something written on the back of the document, it is not a treasure map. Written on the back of the Declaration of Independence were the words ""Original Declaration of Independence dated 4th July 1776"". The text appears on the bottom of the document, upside down. While no one knows for certain who wrote it, it is known that early in its life, the large parchment document (it measures 29¾ inches by 24½ inches) was rolled up for storage. So, it is likely that the notation was added simply as a label."

src: Valsts neatkarības pirmsākumos Singapūras Botāniskā dārza kompetence palīdzēja pārveidot salu par tropisko dārzu pilsētu. 1981. gadā orhidejas hibrīds „Vanda Miss Joaquim” tika izvēlēts par valsts nacionālo ziedu.
mt: 1981, the orchid hybrid Vanda Miss Joaquim was chosen as the national flower of Singapore.
ref: Early in the nation's independence, Singapore Botanic Gardens' expertise helped to transform the island into a tropical Garden City. In 1981, Vanda Miss Joaquim, an orchid hybrid, was chosen as the nation's national flower.

src: Valsts neatkarības pirmsākumos Singapūras Botāniskā dārza kompetence palīdzēja pārveidot salu par tropisko dārzu pilsētu. 1981. gadā orhidejas hibrīds „Vanda Miss Joaquim” tika izvēlēts par valsts nacionālo ziedu.
mt: 1981, the orchid hybrid Vanda Miss Joaquim was chosen as the national flower of Singapore.
ref: Early in the nation's independence, Singapore Botanic Gardens' expertise helped to transform the island into a tropical Garden City. In 1981, Vanda Miss Joaquim, an orchid hybrid, was chosen as the nation's national flower.

src: Lai arī piramīdu celtniecība no akmeņiem turpinājās līdz pat Vecās Karalistes pastāvēšanas beigām, Gīzas piramīdas pēc sava lieluma un būvniecības izcilā tehniskā izpildījuma tā arī palika nepārspētas. Senie Jaunās valsts ēģiptieši apbrīnoja savu priekšteču pieminekļus, kuri tolaik bija vairāk nekā tūkstoš gadus veci.
mt: Although pyramid construction continued until the end of the Old Kingdom, the Great Pyramid of Giza remained the largest and most technologically advanced structure of its kind. The ancient Egyptians of the New Kingdom admired their predecessors' monuments, which were then more than a thousand years old.
ref: Although pyramid-building in stone continued until the end of the Old Kingdom, the pyramids of Giza were never surpassed in their size and the technical excellence of their construction. New Kingdom ancient Egyptians marvelled at their predecessors monuments, which were then well over a thousand year old.

src: Ik gadu ap oktobri gandrīz 1,5 miljoni zālēdāju no ziemeļiem migrē uz dienvidu prērijām, šķērsojot Maras upi, lai pārlaistu lietus sezonu. Beidzoties lietiem, ap aprīli tie dodas atpakaļ uz ziemeļiem, rietumdaļā atkal šķērsojot Maras upi. Serengeti reģionā atrodas Serengeti nacionālais parks, Ngorongoro dabas aizsardzības zona, Masvas medību rezervāts Tanzānijā un Masajas Maras nacionālais rezervāts Kenijā.
mt: 1.5 million wildebeest migrate north from the Serengeti plains to the Mara River every October. After the rains, in April, they return south again, crossing the Mara River. The Serengeti region includes the Serengeti National Park, the Ngorongoro Conservation Area, the Masai Mara Game Reserve in Tanzania and the Maasai Mara National Reserve in Kenya.
ref: Every year around October nearly 1.5 million herbivores travel towards the southern plains, crossing the Mara River, from the northern hills for the rains. And then back to the north through the west, once again crossing the Mara river, after the rains in around April. The Serengeti region contains the Serengeti National Park, the Ngorongoro Conservation Area and Maswa Game Reserve in Tanzania and the Maasai Mara National Reserve in Kenya.
